awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: New Modes of State Governance and Mobile Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The relationship between mobile populations and state interventions is long, complex, and contradictory. Geopolitical tensions have intensified state presence in remote areas such mobile populations face various challenges in resisting and adapting to state formations. This doctoral dissertation project studies how modes of mobility are impacted by state bureaucracy, infrastructure, and regulation. By investigating how people navigate complex state bureaucratic systems that require major shifts to their lives, this dissertation research advances scientific understandings of how communities experience the complexities and opportunities of new infrastructure in both locally specific and broadly similar ways. Findings from this research will be disseminated to better understand state development projects that seem banal but might instead be major and meaningful changes for people. While building roads and requiring different forms of licensure seem to encourage safer and more accessible mobility, how are they actually experienced on the ground? This project also brings historically underrepresented and geographically significant groups into the discovery process of scientific knowledge.   

This doctoral research project investigates local and individual experiences of state formation through an ethnographic study of the role of legalized and certified mobility in modes of new state bureaucratic governance. This research examines (1) how mobility is remade under new forms of state road regulations, driving license requirements, and discipline around mobility and (2) how individuals experience, navigate, adapt, and respond to these new forms of state intervention in their day-to-day lives. Research methods for this project consist of ethnographic participant observation, semi-structured interviews, ethnographic fieldnotes, oral histories of mobile communities, and reviews of official documents. Data analysis will focus on both contextualizing nomads’ experiences of state interventions and situating this study in relation to similar cases elsewhere in the world. In doing so, this research contributes to scientific theories of state formation, Indigenous knowledge, modes of bureaucratic infrastructures, and state development projects as modernization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcome Report: New Modes of State Governance and Mobile Communities

This doctoral research project explores how mobility is shaped, regulated, and experienced under state and corporate-built infrastructures in contemporary governance. By focusing on public infrastructure, both physical (e.g., roads and buildings) and immaterial (e.g., techno-bureaucratic, digital), the research investigates how these systems vacuum individuals' mobility, both physically and mentally into hegemonic governance. Grounded in 18 months months of community-focused ethnographic research on traditionally mobile communities in East Asia, this study sheds light on how state expansion and regulation through infrastructural management impact people's ways of navigating their environments and interacting with systems of governance.

Infrastructural Demands and Biases   

Public infrastructures built by the state or state-owned corporates—whether physical or techno-bureaucratic—are often portrayed as neutral and accessible to all. However, this research reveals that these systems are embedded with coercive practices and biases, often favoring dominant cultural, linguistic, and ethnic groups while sidelining minorities. The governmentality of state regulated infrastructure therefore produces and reproduces majorities and minorities.    

On the surface, public roads appear to be free and accessible to all. However, the reality is that only those who meet the financial demand, possesses bodily skills, mental knowledge, and legal certification requirements can use the roads. For example, public roads are typically designed for motor vehicles, and while they are presented as accessible to all, their use requires significant financial and systemic participation, including vehicle ownership, registration fees, insurance, driving licenses, and highway tolls. In some areas, toll costs are nearly equivalent to fuel expenses, making these infrastructures financially unaffordable for certain populations, while profiting those who regulate and own them. Thus, public roads that are presented as free, neutral, and accessible to all are, in fact, come with various conditions. Those who don’t meet the conditions are left out.   

Additionally, these infrastructures frequently exclude individuals who lack cultural, linguistic, and legal fluency that are required to participate in these infrastructures. For instance, road names, driving tests, and insurance processes are often designed with monolingual assumptions, or limited choices, making it challenging for minorities who do not speak the dominant language to navigate these systems. For example, when one language in a country dominates all aspects of experience, both public and personal, other-minority language speakers are forced to learn the dominant language while further marginalized from their own culture and language. These issues exist in countries worldwide with vast diverse society but less acknowledged their diversity in the public infrastructures in many aspects.

Infrastructural Governance

This research highlights how infrastructures, under the guise of modernization and equality, often impose singular and standardized forms of mobility. They constrain alternative ways of moving and living, while simultaneously serving as tools for state regulation and presence in individuals' daily lives. For example, in recent years, new roads and internet facilities are built in remote areas to modernize and bring economic prosperity. In order to participate in these new infrastructures, all sort of certification including, driver’s license, other forms of IDs, facial recognition, etc., are required. Through these series of demands and obligations, certifying and legalizing mobility, individuals and communities experience infrastructural governance in day-to-day life. By exposing how infrastructures become mediums of state and corporate presence and power, this research project enriches theories of power, state formation, mobility, bureaucratic infrastructure, standardization, and modernization projects.

Towards an Equitable and Diverse Infrastructural Environment

The findings from this research illuminate the coercive, indoctrinate, and exclusionary nature of state-built and corporate-operated infrastructures, both physical and non-physical, which are often implemented in the name of modernization and public good for all. By exposing these biases and limitations, the research contributes to a broader understanding of how infrastructures, both physical and non-physical can unintentionally (or intentionally) marginalize certain populations while promote the power of the state, corporations, and the dominant population.

This knowledge has the potential to influence future policymakers, infrastructure designers, and participants of these systems to be cautious and create more diverse, inclusive, and equitable systems. Acknowledging these infrastructural biases and hegemonic forms can spark important conversations about designing alternative pathways for individuals excluded from worldwide structural systems. Ultimately, the research advocates for a more thoughtful and inclusive approach to infrastructure development, ensuring it better serves diverse populations and mitigates systemic inequalities.
